update.description: Currently the transport publisher drops messages silently. This patch generates a warning when this occurs. As noted in the bug report, dropped messages were reported when contact between simple shapes was generated, as shown in [this video](https://vimeo.com/57230635).
update.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

pullrequest.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

content.raw: As a user, I would like to know which topics are overrunning the queue. So far I've only ever seen ~/pose/info do it, but in my opinion, it's useful to have the warning on a per-publisher basis.
content.html: As a user, I would like to know which topics are overrunning the queue. So far I've only ever seen ~/pose/info do it, but in my opinion, it's useful to have the warning on a per-publisher basis.

pull_request.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

pullrequest.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

content.html:
This flag is set on a per-publisher basis. So, multiple different publishers could output the warning message. You could make queueLimitWarned a static variable inside this function, which will cause the warning message to be printed only once:

{
  static bool queueLimitWarned = false
  ...
  if (!queueLimitWarned)
    queueLimitWarned = true
  ...
}

pull_request.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

pullrequest.title: Fix for Issue #365: warn when messages are dropped

content.raw:
I really like the cmake macro; anything that makes setting up unit tests easier will make them more likely to occur.

Also, to clarify, the `gzlog` logging mechanism is an output stream, not the command-line tool.

Also, I updated this pull request to `gzwarn` the first time the queue limit is reached, with a message indicating that future warnings would be directed to a log file. Also, I put the path to the log file, but if that changes, the message will be out of date.
content.html:
I really like the cmake macro; anything that makes setting up unit tests easier will make them more likely to occur.

Also, to clarify, the gzlog logging mechanism is an output stream, not the command-line tool.

Also, I updated this pull request to gzwarn the first time the queue limit is reached, with a message indicating that future warnings would be directed to a log file. Also, I put the path to the log file, but if that changes, the message will be out of date.

content.raw:
I've updated this pull request to incorporate a logging mechanism that can accessed via `gzlog`.

There is also a cmake macro to build tests.
content.html:
I've updated this pull request to incorporate a logging mechanism that can accessed via gzlog.

There is also a cmake macro to build tests.

content.raw: I just tested it with Atlas, and it sends several hundred warnings at start up when standing still. This warning is unacceptable as-is.

content.raw: Do we have a separate path for messages to go to a log file vs. console?  It would be good to disable or throttle output of these warnings to console but to include all of them in the log file for later debugging.
content.html: Do we have a separate path for messages to go to a log file vs. console? It would be good to disable or throttle output of these warnings to console but to include all of them in the log file for later debugging.

content.raw: Can the same thing happen on the other side, where a subscriber's queue fills up and new messages from the wire are dropped (e.g., because the subscriber is running slowly)?
content.html: Can the same thing happen on the other side, where a subscriber's queue fills up and new messages from the wire are dropped (e.g., because the subscriber is running slowly)?

content.raw: I updated this pull request to merge into default. I'm hesitant to pull this into gazebo_1.4 because there are likely many cases when it's acceptable to drop messages on the floor.
